results.title: Weather: hot
results.creator_credit: Caroline Jones and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
An educational series aimed at 6-8 year olds which covers a variety of subject areas such as weather, transport, space, people and celebrations. When it is hot outside, people wear shorts and t-shirts, drink lots of water, and modify their usual activities to help keep cool. The question is why do we do this? Suitable for children aged 3-7, this video describes how changes in weather affect people, plants and animals differently and the different methods each use to adapt and cope with the heat; what a thermometer is and what it does; how to observe and monitor changes in the weather; and why it is important to dress appropriately when it is hot outside. Also briefly discusses the sun as an energy source.

results.title: Celebrations: achievement
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
A short program aimed at children aged 4-8 narrated by Carolyn Jones showing the different ways that people celebrate achieving certain goals. Following a group of year 7 students to their graduation from school, comparing their preparation and celebration to a group of Police Force cadets preparing to graduate from the Academy. Also discussed is the importance of acknowledging all achievements, no matter how small they may seem.

results.title: Flexibility and body composition
results.creator_credit: Steve Henschel, Stephen Netburn and Walt Disney Educational Media Company
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Fit to Be You”.
Explains the relationship of body mass to body fat in maintaining proper body composition and the importance of keeping that well-composed body flexible through the burning of calories. A witty animated sequence shows the interrelationship of individual basal metabolism, calorie intake and the maintenance of a balanced diet.

results.title: Weather: sunshine
results.creator_credit: Janet Lane and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
An educational series aimed at 6-8 year olds which covers a variety of subject areas such as weather, transport, space, people and celebrations. This short video describes how the sun creates shadows on the ground and reflections on the water; how as the world rotates, the sun sets on one side of the world and rises on the other; and how people and animals use the sun differently. Suitable for children aged 3-7.

results.title: Weather: cold
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “For the juniors”.
This educational video for children covers the topic of cold weather. There are scenes of frosty mornings and the reasons why nights can be so cold, especially when they are cloudless. There are ways and reasons to stay warm and how animals like sheep and horses keep warm during the cold months. The video explains how penguins and whales stay warm, mentioning migration and hibernation as ways animals survive the cold weather. Cold weather and seasons are also important to explain why you can’t buy vegetables all year round.

results.title: Torpedo bombers = Torpedonostsy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Films of the great victory 1941-1945”.
By interspersing historical footage with fictional narrative, this film attempts to present the precarious fighting conditions for WW2 Russian bomber pilots. The filmmaker ably captures the taxing environment in which battles were conducted and the constant danger to those serving in the armed forces. It also depicts the fraught personal lives of the pilots, under strain from wartime conditions. Based on the stories by Yuri German.

results.title: Ivan's childhood = Ivanovo Detstvo [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Andrei Tarkovsky, G Natanson and Mosfilm
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Films of the great victory 1941-1945”.
Tarkovsky’s prize-winning debut feature is an extraordinarily moving view of war and revenge. Twelve year-old Ivan is determined to avenge his mother’s death, and he joins a Russian regiment as a scout. His ability to slip through enemy lines more easily than an adult makes him useful to the army, but, as his missions become increasingly dangerous, it is decided that he must be removed from the front line. Ivan resists and convinces his commanding officers to allow him to carry out one last expedition. The monochrome photography depicts Ivan’s war in a series of memorable sequences, and contributes to making this film one of cinema’s great statements on war. Also available on VHS [311666].
results.description:

results.title: Come and see = Idi i smotri
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Films of the great victory 1941-1945”.
Highly acclaimed Russian feature about a young boy, living in occupied territory, who joins the partisans to fight against the Nazis. An expressionistic work of great beauty that depicts abject horror, the narrative, based on true events, is framed as a coming-of-age story. The protagonist, a survivor through chance, is forced to repeatedly witness the awfulness of genocide, rape, destruction and evil, robbing him of youth, innocence and trust. Unforgettably poetic scenes reflect the brutality of victory, magnified through the eyes of a child. Adapted from the book by Ales Adamovich.
